title.narrative: COVID-19 World Bank/Global Water Security & Sanitation Partnership 2016-2021
COVID-19 World Bank/Global Water Security & Sanitation Partnership 2016-2021

description.narrative:
New/additional funds to address COVID-19 "The Global Water Security & Sanitation Partnership 'is a collaboration between Sida (and other donors) and the World Bank's Water Global Practice in order to help create a" water-secure world for all", and to reach its dual goals of both eliminating the extreme poverty as well as to promote greater prosperity for the 40% poorest in each country.
Sida gives a non-earmarked program funding anticipated to go to both drinking water supply, sanitation and hygiene and also to water security and water resource management, with a specific focus on sustainability, inclusiveness, institutions, financing and resilience. The support for the partnership is ia. envisaged to help shape the Bank's investment loans (IDA) for various water-related programs so that these will be designed based poor peoples needs.

Nya medel/medeltillägg för att bekämpa covid-19 Världsbanken genomgick 2014 en omfattande omorganisation där de olika sektorer som banken arbetade med samlades i sk. Global practices, av vilka vatten var en: Water Global Practice. Genom att samla i princip all vattenrelaterad verksamhet, med undantag för investeringslånen (IDA), inom en enhet kan banken ta ett större helhetsgrepp och bättre än tidigare koppla kunskaper och erfarenheter från de fattigdomsinriktade programmen Water & Sanitation Program (med stöd från Sida mfl givare 2012-2016) samt Water Partnership Program (med stöd av andra givare) till bankens låneverksamhet inom vattensektorn som helhet. 'The Global Water Security & Sanitation Partnership' (GWSP) är ett samarbete mellan Sida och andra givare och Världsbankens organisatoriska entitet Water Global Practice i syfte att bidra till att skapa en "vattensäker värld för alla", och till att uppnå bankens dubbla mål om att dels elliminera den extrema fattigdomen och dels till att främja ökat välstånd för de 40% fattigaste i varje land till 2030. Genom Sidas stöd till partnerskapet förväntas banken därmed på ett väsentligt sätt kunna bidra till genomförandet av Agenda 2030 och ett flertal av de 17 globala utevcklingsmålen, men med fokus framför allt på mål 6 för vatten.
Sida föreslår att ett icke-öronmärkt programstöd beviljas med ett speciellt uppföljningsfokus på dels dricksvattenförsörjning, sanitet och hygien och dels för vattensäkerhet och vattenresursförvaltning, men också utifrån bankens prioriterade teman för hållbarhet; inkludering av fattiga, sårbara och marginaliserade grupper; stärkta institutioner; innovativ/alternativ finansiering samt ökad grad av resiliens och minskad sårbarhet hos partnerländer. Sidas stöd till partnerskapet kommer främst att utgöras av finansiering av teknisk expertis för att utforma bankens investeringslån (IDA) för olika vattenrelaterade program i partnerländerna, utifrån fattiga människors behov för att därigenom kunna lyfta framför allt de mest utsatta grupperna ut fattigdom och samtidigt skapa möjligheter för att bidra till utveckling av ländernas ekonomier.
Sida har under ca två års tid tillsammans med andra givare, bl.a. UK, Holland, Norge, Finland, Schweiz, Gates Foundation samt USAID varit aktiv i dialogen kring utformningen av GWSP's projektdokument och resultatramverk. GWSPs fem 'affärsområden' bl.a. - vattenförsörjning och sanitet samt vattensäkerhet och vattenresursförvaltning - bygger på de ansatser och metoder som bla. utvecklats under Sidas stöd 2012-2015 till Water & Sanitation Programme, men också genom andra givares stöd till Water Partnership Programme.
Särskild vikt har vid förhandlingarna med banken lagts på partnerskapets resultatramverk. Sida avser att vara aktiv i partnerskapets råd och delta i dialog och uppföljning av bl.a. uppdateringar av budget och resultatramverk i konsultation med övriga berörda givare, i samband med det första rådsmötet som planeras till början av 2017.
Programmets totala budget beräknas för perioden 2017-2021 uppgå till ca 1 776 MSEK (200 MUSD). Sidas bidrag för 2016-2019 föreslås uppgå till 210 MSEK.
Under förutsättning att banken erhåller full finansiering (dvs 200 MUSD) för GWSP förväntas det föreslagna programmet under 2017-2021 bidra till att, på basis av partnerskapets finansiering av tekniskt stöd för fattigdomsanpassning av investeringslånen, uppnå följande resultat:
För vattenförsörjning och sanitet • 70 miljoner fler människor får tillgång till förbättrad vattenkällor • 80 miljoner fler människor får tillgång till förbättrad sanitet • 25 000 ton föroreningsbelastning har avlägsnats genom reningsverk • 13 miljoner fler människor har utbildats om handhygien • 90 vattenverk har förbättrat sin funktionalitet
För vattensäkerhet och integrerad vattenresursförvaltning • Genomförande av riskreducerande åtgärder, bla. avsende torka eller översvämningar, som direkt påverkar 16 miljoner och och indirekt 60 miljoner människor • 140 flodavrinningsområden med förvaltningsplaner och mekanismer för att engagera berörda intressenter • 120 institutioner med uppföljnings- och övervakningssystem för vattenresursförvaltning • 1,3 miljoner hektar mark och/eller vattenområden förvaltas på ett hållbart sätt.
Dessa förväntade resultat kan dock komma att skrivas ned om den nuvarande underfinansieringen kommer att kvarstå. Idagsläget har banken säkrat ca 55% av den planerad budgetramen. Finland, Danmark, Österrike, USAID samt UK har ännu inte heller meddelat om stöd kommer att ges och ej heller om möjlig omfattning. Om underfinansieringen bedöms fortsätta under 2017 och framåt behöver Sida resa krav på att banken presenterar en reviderad budget utifrån nödvändiga prioriteringar av aktiviteter/verksamheter samt nedskrivning av förväntade resultat.
Sidas bedömning är dock att det kommer att finnas tillräckligt med medel i fonden för att den ska kunna bli operationell från 2017-01-01.
Det bilagda avtalsutkastet bygger på en av Sida ny beslutad och med banken förhandlad mall för multigivarfonder.

participating-org.narrative: International Bank for Reconstruction and Development

sector.narrative: Basic drinking water supply and basic sanitation

tag.narrative: 13.1 - Strengthen resilience and adaptive capacity to climate-related hazards and natural disasters in all countries.
13.1 - Stärka motståndskraften mot och förmågan till anpassning till klimatrelaterade faror och naturkatastrofer i alla länder.
6.1 - Senast 2030 uppnå allmän och rättvis tillgång till säkert och ekonomiskt överkomligt dricksvatten för alla.
6.1 - By 2030, achieve universal and equitable access to safe and affordable drinking water for all.

6.2 - By 2030, achieve access to adequate and equitable sanitation and hygiene for all and end open defecation, paying special attention to the needs of women and girls and those in vulnerable situations.

6.2 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla har tillgång till fullgod och rättvis sanitet och hygien och att ingen behöver uträtta sina behov utomhus. Särskild uppmärksamhet bör ägnas åt behoven hos kvinnor och flickor samt människor i utsatta situationer.

6.4 - By 2030, substantially increase water-use efficiency across all sectors and ensure sustainable withdrawals and supply of freshwater to address water scarcity and substantially reduce the number of people suffering from water scarcity.

6.4 - Till 2030 väsentligt effektivisera vattenanvändningen inom alla sektorer samt säkerställa hållbara uttag och en hållbar försörjning med sötvatten för att angripa vattenbristen och väsentligt minska det antal människor som lider av vattenbrist.
6.5 - By 2030, implement integrated water resources management at all levels, including through transboundary cooperation as appropriate.
6.5 - Senast 2030 genomföra en integrerad förvaltning av vattenresurser på alla nivåer, när så är lämpligt genom gränsöverskridande samarbete.

6.a - By 2030, expand international cooperation and capacity-building support to developing countries in water- and sanitation-related activities and programmes, including water harvesting, desalination, water efficiency, wastewater treatment, recycling and reuse technologies.

6.a - Till 2030 utöka det internationella samarbetet och stödet för kapacitetsuppbyggnad till utvecklingsländerna inom vatten- och sanitetsrelaterade verksamheter och program, inklusive genom tekniker för vatteninsamling, avsaltning, vatteneffektivitet, rening av avloppsvatten, återvinning och återanvändning.

description.narrative: The GWSP annual report “Connecting the Drops” delivered on the 4th of November, 2019 covers results from July 2018 through June 2019, describes GWSP’s results and the impact it has made as it concludes its second year of operation. Sida’s support to the program started at the end of 2016, and in November a decision was taken by the Director General to add 209 MSEK for the period 2020-2021 from funds via INTEM/SOCIAL and INTEM/GLOBEN. In this regard the thorough review of the report, results, challenges, was done jointly by SOCIAL and GLOBEN. Below are some highlights of relevant results presented in the annual report, which has been assessed to be a very informative report that clearly presents the five priority themes of GWSP’s Results Framework (Resilience, Inclusion, Sustainability, Institutions, and Finance) and what is being measured, including framework results which are built into three blocks or levels of the program, which are: Blocks A, B, and C. (Block A - tracks "direct results" from activities funded by the GWSP, i.e., outputs in the form of development of policies, strategies, regulatory frameworks, development of knowledge products, strengthening water sector actors etc.; Block B - tracks the impact of GWSP funded activities on the WGP itself, ie. outcomes in terms of institutional changes and leveraged effects on design and implementation of lending operations; Block C - tracks combined outcomes of GWSP-funded activities and lending operations at country level, and results from technical assistance and knowledge work, and lending operations in nine countries: Bangladesh, Benin, Bolivia, Egypt, Ethiopia, Haiti, Pakistan, Uganda, Vietnam). Although reporting on Block C countries was not expected to be done until 2020 (as previously agreed by all donors in the GWSP Council), some results from this block have been included this year. In this regard it is worth mentioning that there are some results that can be of interest to Sida bilateral programs, specifically countries where there is support to the water, environment, and health sectors, i.e. Bolivia, Bangladesh, Ethiopia, Uganda, Vietnam.) Highlights of results achieved during FY18-19: •172 million people, including 86 million women and girls, received access to improved sanitation.•2.9 million farmers, 0.6 million of whom are female, adopted improved agricultural technology.•5 million people now live in areas covered by water risk mitigation measures.•12,900 tons/year of biochemical oxygen demand (BOD) pollution loads were removed by treatment plants; and 0.7 million hectares of land were provided with new or improved irrigation services. •In FY19, GWSP’s knowledge and analytics influenced a total of $13.7 billion in water lending operations, including $1.4 billion in countries affected by fragility, conflict and violence (FCV). •GWSP provided resources so Tajikistan’s Dushanbe Vodokanal Water and Sanitation Utility could launch outreach and recruitment programs at universities and technical schools to boost inclusion.•GWSP’s analysis on closing the gender gap in the water workforce contributed to securing additional financing for the Greater Beirut Water Supply project to support trainings for female employees from Lebanon’s Beirut Mount Lebanon Water Establishment utility. •GWSP supported the government of Bangladesh in demonstrating how to leverage microfinance and technical assistance to support rural and low-income households and construction companies in purchasing and installing hygienic latrines. Highlights of knowledge reports which were published and presented during FY18—19. These include “original research” that “shape” the global water agenda and were all launched with extensive communications packages and received global media coverage: • Quality Unknown, The Invisible Water Crisis • Integrating Green and Gray Infrastructure• Doing More with Less - Smarter Subsidies for Water Supply and Sanitation • Women in Water Utilities. For Sida it was also positive to see that many results refer to work that stems from the work initiated in the earlier Water and Sanitation Program (WSP) and the Water Partnership Program (WPP) phases, and which has continued under GWSP or through ongoing World Bank operations. One example of this is the results presented from the WASH Poverty Diagnostics Program which was largely supported by Sida via the WSP program, and which “continue to advance the water agenda years after analyses are completed by influencing policy and implementation.” Important and relevant results of the WPD and how they have influenced are presented in page 29 of the annual report. TABLE 1: Influence and Impact of Findings from WASH Poverty Diagnostics, Selected Countries and Economies. The annual report was presented at the 2019 Annual GWSP Council meetings 17-22/11 2019 - The focus on results was on the five themes of the program which are Sustainability; Resilience; Institutions; Inclusion; and Financing. The following is a brief summary of presentations at the Council meetings on the highlights of the report focusing on the five themes: (The various presentations by Senior leadership and Program Managers of the WB Water GP were made at this meeting- for reasons related to GDRP in this document there are no names but are referred here as (SL) ). SL presented on GWSP’s achievements during its second year of program implementation and on the way forward. These included: (i) the increase in the number of countries and analytics that GWSP support and financing influenced in terms of World Bank lending; (ii) the key highlights of the global challenges and opportunities for each theme; (iii) GWSP finances; and, (iv) key results from fiscal year (FY) 2019 As an example of the global knowledge work being undertaken was presented on the global water quality picture. Research shows that the world faces an invisible crisis of water quality with wider, deeper, and more uncertain impacts than previously thought. Poor water quality threatens growth, harms public health and imperils food security. The outlook is stark - but change is possible. The attendees welcomed work done in this area and encouraged the World Bank to continue to advance this key agenda. To highlight the ongoing and planned process of knowledge into implementation, demonstrated the impact on policy and programmatic initiatives as a result of the WASH Poverty Diagnostics and (SL) discussed the potential impact of planned Public Expenditure Review Diagnostics on public finance and the ability to close the financing gap in order to reach SDG6. During the Annual Council meetings, a series of presentations were given by Water GP staff focused on key global initiatives and results in select thematic priorities and client countries, some examples or relevant results include the following: Institutions (SL) presented on the role of institutions in the Water Supply and Sewerage Program in Shimla, India and how they can contribute to achieving 24/7 water supply and 100% sewerage connections by 2024. (SL) spoke about ongoing efforts to bring irrigation services to one of the poorest and most vulnerable areas of Malawi. Resilience (SL) showcased examples of global, regional and country based operations, studies and advocacy that illustrate how GWSP is putting water at the heart of resilience and resilience at the heart of water. Berina Uwimbabazi explained how support from GWSP helped show the potential for integrated water resources development in the Western Balkans, informing joint decisions and investments in the region. (SL) offered insights into operating in post-conflict settings and the importance of working with local stakeholders. He highlighted examples from Somalia. (SL) showed how small island countries can offer significant lessons for others in addressing water resilience challenges. Inclusion (SL) presented on the World Bank’s current initiatives supporting inclusion, including increased effort to mainstream inclusion, with special reference to promoting female participation in water jobs. The discussion including references to disabilities, low disbursement rates, and enhanced support for implementation.(SL) gave an example of this inclusion work with his presentation on a gender audit on Haiti and how it was raising awareness and driving change. (SL) focused on Menstrual Hygiene Management (MHM) in WASH projects in Ghana, highlighting the 2,000 schools that have provided MHM training to students. (SL) showed how child hygiene and nutrition were core elements of WASH projects in Laos. Finance (SL) reviewed GWSP’s strategy to enhance efforts to tackle the financing gap in the sector, including addressing foundational issues, blending financing and leveraging private finance. (SL) presented on the first public sector guarantee in water to support a $1 billion project in Angola. (SL) described a new approach to reducing non-revenue water through a performance-based contract, currently being trialed in Ho Chi Minh, supported by data and technical assistance. (SL) described the hybrid annuity model that has been used to fund the protection of the Ganga river through improved sewage management. Sustainability (SL) highlighted the sustainability issues facing the sector and GWSP supported efforts in FY19 to address these challenges. (SL) also provided background on the water security diagnostics in terms of standardizing the approach and opening a comprehensive dialogue with clients in order to facilitate an integrated water management approach. (SL) presented on using the dam safety decision support framework to improve the sustainability of dams, particularly how policy interventions enhance dam quality and safety. (SL) called for ‘business as unusual’ when it comes to delivering sanitation in cities in developing countries and gave examples of GWSP support to clients and World Bank lending operations. (SL) highlighted the focus and measurement of sustainability on a Project for Results rural water and sanitation project in Vietnam. GWSP Implementation and Administration Knowledge into Implementation: A dialogue with Water GP Practice Managers highlighted some of the challenges they are facing and how they are using knowledge to address them and build major findings into their dialogues with client countries. For example, (SL) gave several examples of how GWSP analytics has informed work in the East Asia Pacific region for both WASH and water resource management initiatives. (SL) gave an overview of activities in Latin America and focused on two examples in Peru where the water security diagnostics is influencing the policy dialogue and analytical work identified opportunities to enhance circular economy opportunities on reuse and renewables. (SL) highlighted the use of GWSP knowledge in scaling up city-wide sanitation in Addis Ababa. The approach has included working closely with the water utility to change internal culture and improve staff training. Donors highlighted their priorities as: Integrity and Transparency, Inclusion, Resilience/Adaptation/Climate Change: This remains a priority and continued work highlighting the impact on water at the global, regional, national and subnational work was endorsed. Sustainable Development Goals: It was suggested that in the next Annual Report, reference be made to linkages with the SDGs to assist with specific donors reporting requirements. This is particularly useful in work that supports the SDGs beyond SGG 6.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

strategy.title: Sustainable environment, climate, oceans and use of natural resources 2018-2022
strategy.titleSV: Hållbar miljö, hållbart klimat och hav samt hållbart nyttj. av naturresurser 2018-2022
